excellent location, close to most attractive spots in nyc. very nice, helpful, well trained staff. well appointed designer rooms with large bed, fancy lamps, larg tv, tea or coffee making machine, we were surprised that the hotel was not able to clean our bath rooms floor, after having asked 5 times, yes 5 times! the front desk, house keeping, chaimber maids we just gave up. We avoided to walk bare foot in the room. heating is very loud, so turn off at night.breakfast was overpriced.

First the good news .... Rooms are spotlessly clean; the decor is fresh and modern; the beds a good size and comfortable; space is at a premium but the designers have made the best use of it; the location is fantastic and the young staff are very friendly. The rooms fall a little short in two respects - the double glazing isn't the best so there is a reasonable amount of street noise and the air conditioning is both ferocious and noisy meaning you can't hope to sleep with it on with the result that it can get very warm overnight. On this basis I'd probably normally look to rate as a 4 however I think it's the little things that matter and here I think the hotel falls down slightly. When paying USD350 a night I don't expect to have to pay for wi-fi access (and rarely do in this city). Having asked whether a late check out would be available the price offered for a stay of an extra 3 hours was USD229 + taxes. Given that rooms are still being cleaned at this time I think such requests could be honoured without looking to impose such substantial charges. A request to please pop postcards in the mail with hotel post and add the charge to the bill resulted in directions to the post office - I've never before had a hotel not do this small service for me. These sound like minor gripes but this isn't a cheap hotel and they do impact the overall impression of the service offered. They could be easily addressed though and, if they are, I think the Hyatt would merit a firm rating of 'very good'.

The location is ideal to walk to restaurants and to get to the train. We're located in the north end of Greenwich Village by Union Square and have seen many of the sites easily by train and taxi,The hotel staff at this hotel are very nice. The rooms are clean and there is a refrigerator and a coffee maker, but a microwave would have made it a little better. The towels are soft and supple and the bed is divine. I recommend you consider staying here if you are planning a sight seeing trip to NYC.

We spent 5 nights at the Hyatt Union Square and despite the typical, NYC tight quarters we found the hotel, particularly the staff, to be excellent all around. We were combining business and pleasure and were pleased to arrive to a cupcake, wine and balloons in our room for my husband's birthday. A nice touch and not always the norm in NYC. Overall, the Hyatt Union Square feels a bit more boutique and less Hyatt-chain with excellent staff, amenities and a great location earning it a rare 5-star rating from us. The location on 4th Avenue is fantastic. While the rooms are not inexpensive they are a bargain when you consider the proximity to transportation. It's about a 3 minute walk to Union Square station where you can catch a train, up, down, or around the city. I think 7 different lines run through the various Union Square hubs, making it simple to get anywhere in the city. Buy a fare card and go anywhere. If you prefer cabs they are plentiful and easy to hail. Surroundings are safe, well lit, walk-able neighborhood with shops, restaurants, The Strand bookstore (a must visit), and a variety of boutiques. It's an easy walk to the East Village and not too far even to Greenwich Village proper where bars, clubs, and restaurants abound. The location and wonderful staff make this hotel a real find for those wanting to see all parts of the city.We were traveling with our daughter, son-in-law and grandson so we booked 2 rooms: 1 King and 1 Queen Double, both without terraces. The rooms were more "W" in style with clean, modern, minimalist furnishings. Very new and chic with no wasted space. Closet space is, as expected, tight with 2 bedside armoire-style closets. Both rooms were clean, comfortable, well stocked and convenient to elevators. Our 6th floor rooms were very quiet--with the exception of our 2.5-year-old grandson's noise--but with virtually no street noise. The beds were typical, high-end Hyatt: firm with nice linens and extra bedding/pillows provided. A work area/desk and reliable Internet connection made it easy to work and play on-line. A well-stocked mini-bar had enough room to store a little milk or juice. Ice must be ordered from room service but was promptly provided. The hotel delivered and set-up a pack 'n play for us, which looked brand new including very nice linens. While they don't advertise, or perhaps even intend to be such, the hotel was very toddler-friendly. Bathrooms had rain shower only (no tub), the water pressure was excellent and hot-water was plentiful. Our only minor issue was that the towel supply seemed to be very limited, perhaps due to the limited rack/shelf space, Again, extra towels were promptly delivered on request. The staff from front-desk to housekeeping were uniformly 5-star! They were all unfailingly helpful, friendly and seeming happy to provide any and every assistance needed. Our stand-out person from this trip was a host, Daquan, who was fantastic with our grandson and a happy, friendly face each day of our stay. His willingness to help locate my bags after I lost my claim ticket went above & beyond! I hope the Hyatt appreciates him, John at the front desk, and the rest of their excellent crew at Union Square! In addition to the hotel itself, we enjoyed the SINGL bar which also has a minimalist, W hotel feel to it. They have a nice whiskey selection, interesting drink menu, good service and ample, comfortable seating. A bit pricey (but what hotel bar isn't?) but a great place to relax with a drink or grab a snack at the end of the day. On Friday evenings they have a jazz quartet which truly enhanced the mellow, relaxing atmosphere. As elsewhere in the hotel, the service exceeded expectations. We enjoyed breakfast at the bistro-style hotel restaurant and while the food was very good, the wait staff was just fantastic in accommodating our family group. A great start to your day for coffee and pastries or heartier fare in a sunny, street-side space.We highly recommend a stay at the Union Square Hyatt and hope to return on our next visit to NYC.

The Hyatt Hotel at Union Square New York is a new relatively small boutique hotel. The building retains the facade of an earlier old building but the interior has been gutted and all new accommodations built in. Our room was compact but definitely of superior quality with stylish modern decor and quality fittings. Everything was spotless. The check-in area was attentively manned with very helpful and courteous staff who were only too pleased to help with enquiries and queries. The reception area has comfortable seating and free wi-fi. A large bar lounge behind check-in looked very comfortable and was well patronised. We only had one night at the hotel prior to sailing home on Queen Mary 2 and we opted to eat in the restaurant tied to the hotel called The Fourth. This is a very good restaurant and we ate well, although it was a tad pricey. All in all we were very impressed with the hotel and we would certainly return there if business takes us that way again.

I stayed here for convention in the city for a few days. Awesome Awesome Place. I lived in this neighborhood 10 years ago and it was nice to be back. The hotel staff is supper attentive, the rooms were a decent size for NYC and you can't beat the location. My wife was able to do yoga at several studios within walking distance. I'm not sure why this isn't an Andaz; it adheres to the Andaz philosophy more than the Andaz midtown location. For those of you who went clubbing in the 90's and 2000's the lobby is the old Kit Kat and Spa Night club. If I have to stretch for one complaint; they could've used another elevator. Can't wait to go back for pleasure.
user_location: West Orange, New Jersey, United States

review_body: I was at Hyatt last month on business. Had a very good stay - spacious room, great breakfast at the Fourth and lovely staff. On business plan, even had my suit ironed every day!At Union square, this hotel is at an excellent location.

My wife and I recently spent 4 nights in one of their ADA king rooms. Based on ADA rooms at other hotels, I was hesitant to book one because, in my opinion, they typically aren't as nice as the other rooms in a hotel. At the Hyatt Union Square, we found their ADA rooms to be much nicer than others I have stayed in, and I would not hesitate to stay in one at this hotel again.There was a mix-up with our reservation that we found out about when we arrived. Our reservation for the last night of our stay was inadvertently cancelled by the Hyatt customer service rep, and we didn't know that until check-in. In addition, there were very few Hyatt rooms left in Manhattan for that night, so we were a little anxious about what we were going to do. The next day, William, the front-office manager straightened everything out and honored our previously booked rate at the Hyatt US for that last night, which was a big relief. Thanks, William! Other positives:- The location of the hotel is great. It is a block south of Union Square and the US subway station with multiple lines. Plus, it is easy to walk to many destinations all over Manhattan from the hotel.- There are tons of restaurants and bars to choose from in the area.- The lobby and rooms are very modern in style, clean and look new.- Staff was always friendly and helpful.- Room was amazingly quiet for the middle of NYC. Aside from some noisy guests in the hallway one night, we didn't hear noises through the walls. The windows also seemed great at keeping street noises out up on the 5th floor.- The bed was very comfortable- We actually had a view of the street from our room. Too often in NYC, a hotel window gives a view of a brick wall that is 3 ft away.- Great, rain shower head and water pressure- Nice shampoo, conditioner and soap provided- They offer an “intimacy kit” in the in-room snack/amenities bar. I have never seen that before but thought it was a great idea.Negatives:- Our shower shared a room with the toilet. Because the shower was open, most of the floor in that room got wet during a shower. I am not sure if this layout/design is due to it being an ADA room or not. It wasn't a huge deal, but was a little inconvenient if you wanted to use the toilet after a shower.- The open, modern design of the bathroom doesn't give you much privacy when using the bathroom or showering. This wasn't a big deal for my wife and I, but might be for others. Again, this might have been worse due to the ADA room.- My wife and I both thought that the pillows could have been more comfortable. They flattened out too much overnight for our taste.- Wifi was free for us for some reason (is it always free?) but was very slow.Overall, I would not hesitate to stay at this hotel again and would definitely recommend it to family or friends.

Beautiful, new hotel. Only negative is that the rooms were very very small, even the passages were small. The architecture was very different and unique. The service and the staff were very good. Location was ok, not the best a little far away from 5th avenue or times square. Taxis were easy to get, many restaurants in walking distance.

My wife and I recently stayed at the Hyatt for Halloween weekend. The hotel was very clean and newly remodeled. The rooms are generally small with little closet space but that's what you typically get in big cities and high rent areas in this price range. The only problem we had was the A/C was a bit loud and turned off and on without warning and one window didn't lock completely. We loved the location. The hotel is near the subway and park and the neighborhood felt very safe to us coming from L.A. We got in late most nights and had several nice chats with Melissa who worked in the reception area -- she was very welcoming. Also Diana one of the bartenders, was very cool and gave us a great dining recommendation. The staff and location get a solid 4 Stars and the room gets a 3.5 Stars for lack of closet space and noisy A/C.

Stayed here recently when business took my to NYC. The hotel was extremely well decorated & furnished, clean, the staff was friendly. The room was a bit tiny, but it's New York. The location was safe & had many restaurants & shops near by. Taxis are extremely easy to get right outside the front door of the hotel, and the subway is right near by as well.If you do stay here I recommend eating across the street at Pie Face - don't let the name fool you, they serve a lot more than just deserts. Good stuff!

I stayed 6 days at this hotel. As a native New Yorker the location was just absolutely perfect. Centrally located in Union Square, I was amongst some of my favorite haunts in the city. Just a block away from Regal Cinemas and the Strand Book Store, 2 blocks away from Whole Foods and a myriad of restaurants, shopping (5th Avenue 4 blocks away), Union Square Park (Farmers Market), Barnes and Noble with Cafe, a 10 minute walk to Soho and the East Village, 2 blocks away from the subway station (4,5,6,Q,N,R) and much, much more. While a busy area the hotel was not affected by the noise of its surrounding. Room Service was prompt, the fitness center was well stocked, 3 restaurants onsite, and excellent service all round. I know exactly where next to stay when I'm in the city!

This is a really well located hotel, plum in the middle of the city. Bowery is a 10 min walk south. Meatpacking district is 15 mins west, Empire State 15 mins north and Brooklyn is an hours walk over the Williamsburg Bridge East. If you like walking and the sun is out, the views are great going over the bridge.We booked an Alcove Loft, as this was a lowest available rate. We were at the Andaz Wall Street, but decied to stay "uptown". Applied a Diamond Suite Upgrade to it, which caused confusion, as this is actually a suite, so no upgrade. Manager on duty explained it when questioned, so all sorted. Room is a decent size, well kitted out, though bathroom area a bit small. Bar in the restaurant closes quite early. Hotel bar closes 130am ish without notice, which was weird. Would certainly come back next time we're in NY.

My daughter and I headed into the city for a quick visit. Needed a nice hotel with a good price in a central location. I normally stay in Midtown but love the union Square area so thought we would give the Hyatt a try. Brand new, great location just a block off Union Square and the subway station. Staff was wonderful, we arrived early and were given our room.Room is small- typical NYC but well designed and very comfortable. Also very quiet. The whole hotel was very clean. We did not visit the gym or the restaurants so cannot rate those, but you have so many choices in this area. Will definitely return. This location is so convenient to things we want to do and the hotel is perfect.

Stayed here for a weekend to visit NYU. So for that, the location is perfect, just a few blocks from some of the dorms and the main school buildings. The rooms are very new and modern, though it takes a little getting used to - having the shower practically out in the room. But it was clean and comfortable. The front desk staff was very helpful and aimed to please. Downsides were the room rate was expensive, as was the wifi. And as for the maid service, the first morning we found hair from the previous guest splayed across the shower wall. The next morning it was still there because the maid had missed it again. So these things kept it from getting a top rating but we would try it again. On a side note, If you're tempted by the "Pie Face" restaurant across the street, skip it. They didn't have many of the flavors they advertised and the small mini pies were just not that good.

Overall, would I give this another try? yes -- it's a great location and comfortable enough for a Hyatt; however, they have some kinks to work out. I'll give them benefit of the doubt for still being rather new. I would stay here over Times Square any day.Wifi consistency could be improved -- found it slow at times.After feeling like getting snowed checking in about getting such a nice room and upgrade, my room was right across from the elevator for a 4-night stay. lame but I was too tired to request another. The room itself is clean, roomy enough for NY, bed is average, shower is lovely with enough pressure.I found service when calling the front desk for things very prompt, polite, friendly and timely. Breakfast at the Fourth is average -- the service seemed bored and my sunny side up eggs came to me over medium.

Love this hotel! It is convenient to the best of restaurants, shops and public transportation (subways). Accommodating staff and nice amenities. The Fourth offers farm-fresh food in a pleasantly eclectic space. Check out their espresso machine. It is a work of art! Look forward to coming back very soon!

Avoid the tourist masses uptown and settle into a convenient location for your NYC activities. You feel like a VIP as the valet whisks away your car to a secure location. The young efficient staff quickly dispels any notion you may have had about unfriendly New Yorkers with smiles and a super quick check-in. This is Manhattan and space is at a premium for everyone. A "standard" room is on the small side but well designed with every important amenity. The rooms are spotless, comfortable and quiet. We are former long time New Yorkers and make this hotel our go-to spot for city visits. . The hotel is within walking distance to Greenwich Village and comprehensive shopping is around the corner. Union Square Park is next door with a farmer's market, street musicians and landscaped strolling. A major subway station takes you to all of NY quickly and economically.

We dropped into the bar called Singl in the Hyatt lobby, for a brief rest after walking from Battery Park. The waitress was very sweet, the washrooms were perfectly clean and the service excellent. The value for the wine was quite reasonable .

We recently made a 36 hr trip to NYC, travelled all day and arrived at the Hyatt, Union Square at midnight. At that time we were informed that the guests in the room we reserved ( to sleep 3) extended their stay. So sorry, you can go to another location uptown or we have 2 rooms available in different locations . Not only was this really disappointing news it was delivered with indifference, sneers and giggles. I all my years, I have never had this happen. The staff is extremely young and inexperienced. For the ensuing duration we stayed there, the check in staff and manager ignored us upon entering the hotel repeatedly. No eye contact, or "hey, Im really sorry about what happened"...nothing. I asked not to be charged for night #1, but a message left on my phone from the manager said they couldn't do that. I did receive a 50% comp for my stay, but in all sincereity, my family and I were extremely upset for the entire stay. Regarding the rooms... they are very small and very little walking space as the furniture in there is too large for the space. There was no where to put luggage, except on the floor by the door. No true closet and a reluctance from the housekeeping staff when I asked for a few extra towels. The beds are very hard and the mattresses very thin.Wow, all for $700/night. Unfortunately, it takes an awful experience to sit down and write this review. I have had some great stays all over the world since my last review, but didn't take the time to thank them on this forum. I apologize for that and I will do so. The really challenging thing in any industry is when things don't go as planned. True customer service is in how things are handled. I'm sure Mr or Mrs Hyatt would not approve.

The Hyatt in Union Square is in a great downtown location for a visit to NYC. It is a new hotel with high end linens, furniture and staff! The staff checking us in were very friendly and made the process go quickly and smoothly. The room was beautiful and squeaky clean. We were able to secure a good rate through booking.com; I would highly recommend this hotel to anyone looking for a place to stay in the city.

A friend and I shared a room on the 11th floor during a business trip. I really liked the location - I never stayed in Union Square before. There were a lot of restaurants in the area as well as an amazing café across the street called Think Coffee. We never ate at our hotel restaurant - it seemed overpriced for what they were offering. We went to Think Coffee every morning for great coffee and a heathy unprocessed breakfast. We were close to shopping, Soho, our work location, Chelsea market, the subway (had we wanted to take it), and about 20 minutes walk to the Highline. We found the hotel staff to helpful and friendly including the ever smiling maintenance man, Jesus. The room was not huge, but WHO goes to New York to sit in a hotel room? It was fine and the rooms are soundproofed so you don't hear your neighbours or too much outside noise. We were able to open the window slightly which was great for fresh air. What I liked about the room was that the bed was really comfortable. The rooms were very clean and i am very picky. I like that the toilet (with its own air circulation) and shower were both separate from the sink area which makes getting ready in the morning more efficient. I wish there would have been more of a division between the room and sink besides just the large mirror. I would have liked an additional mirror on the other side of the bathroom mirror and more hooks in the room. I liked that there was a wooden floor and no carpet in the room. What I didn't like about the hotel was the heavy scent of room fragrance all over the hotel. It was a nice scent but too strong and made me nauseous if I sat in the lobby for too long. I didn't like that they charge daily for internet when most hotels include it. I also think they could afford to offer a breakfast buffet included in the price which makes it more convenient in the morning. We got a good deal on a different website which made our stay more affordable than the regular price. Would I stay here again? You bet!

We chose the Hyatt for two specific criteria, the availability of 2 queen beds and the location.Our reservation was confirmed by phone and subsequent email. We arrived at midnight and upon entering the lobby area it was as if we did not exist...no greeting, no acknowledgment, nada! When the twenty-something, newly minted NYU hotel management grad decided she would grace us by checking us in the first thing she tells us is we cant have the room we reserved because the guests extended their stay. Tough luck.Then Mr Night Manager Could Care Less joins us and tells us we can have two rooms on the same floor. Oh Goodie, but our reservation was for a room with TWO QUEEN BEDS.Bottom Line- This is a hotel with an arrogant, indifferent staff that makes the experience miserable. Stay somewhere else.

I am a Hyatt Gold Passport Member. I spent over $700 per night on an "alcove suite" which was a tiny, joke of a room at a ridiculous price. Service was bad and apologetic here. The place already looks tacky and dated. The W Union Square is a much better bet. Nothing is good about this hotel. Epic fail.

Had never stayed here before but can only imagine that the hotel has been upgraded significantly since the remodel. Young, hip, small rooms. Staff very enthusiastic and helpful. GREAT location. The only downside was that the bathroom is more or less a part of the actual room itself (not a true divider), but the way they use the vanity helps to create separation. ACs need to be updated as well, but would definitely stay here again.

We stumbled on this hotel during Freshman move in days at NYU. We decided to switch hotels the following weekend and have stayed at this hotel again on a recent trip to NYC for business. Its a great location, new and the staff are very helpful. Rooms can vary in size so be careful when booking. We ate in the restaurant this past visit and while we had to return a meal, the staff was very helpful and they did not charge us for the meal. It feels as if it is going through some growing pains of being a new hotel and training of its staff but I am confident that they will work out any bugs. A much needed hotel in this area!

Great location and very friendly staff. The room was small but efficiently designed. We heard some noise through the windows at night, but it's New York, so nothing unusal. The hotel is fairly new.... opened this year. The mattresses are new Sealy posturpedics, but for some unknown reason I did not find them to be the most comfortable. Also, I regret not asking for hypoallergenic pillows instead of the uncomfortable goose down pillows that were on the bed. The place was extremely clean. As a side note, I did not care for the bar downstairs called Singl. While it was attractive and trendy, the prices are outrageous. After seeing a Broadway show, my partner and I thought we'd have a glass of wine before retiring. We got there about 11:30 and the attendant told us that they were serving "last call", so we said we'd just have a glass of chardonnay and cabernet, but thankfully I inquired "how much" prior to her getting the wine. She said the cabernet was $48! I then replied that we only wanted a glass, not a bottle, and she said "that is the price for a glass". We canceled the order and left without our glass of wine.

The hotel is new and very modern and in a good position. We stayed in a Sky room which was very attractive but small and we thought quite pricey for the size. The check in was efficient however there seemed to only be one elevator working on and off throughout our 3 days and this caused some back up. The staff are young and friendly and try to be helpful. The mini bar items are very expensive as was we thought the wifi. Our only issue was that they failed to give us a wake up call!! But generally a hip modern hotel in a vibrant area of New York.

Completely positive experience... from the excellent location close to the fun Union Square Park and Metro, to the thoughtfully appointed modern rooms. Being new, all the latest ideas are incorporated - funky lighting, blockout curtains, coffee making in the room, light switches that glow so you know where they are in the dark, well placed mats beside the bed. Although the rooms are small, the ceilings were high so there’s a perception of space. This was the most homely of hotels in our month-long stay in the US.

As a frequent visitor to NYC, I have stayed at and reviewed many different hotels in many parts of town. I decided to try this location because I wanted to be close to the major subway lines in Union Square. I found this Hyatt to be a fine choice in an excellent location. The hotel itself is new and modern. The staff is extremely nice and friendly. My room was quiet, clean and comfortable although I did hear my neighbors on a few occasions. Overall I have absolutely no complaints other than the elevators are a bit slow and one of the two was in and out of service during my stay- a minor inconvenience in what was overall a Very Nice Stay. I must compliment the staff who were young and very sweet whenever I had the need to engage them. At checkout there was an error on my bill which was immediately corrected once I pointed it out. I like staying in this part of town and will definitely be back.

This hotel is small and may not look like much from the street but it. Is well run and located in an area of Manhattan where there are relatively few other decent accommodation options. As a result, room prices are steep and occupancy high.The public areas and bedrooms are up-to-date and modern in design. A lively bar on the ground floor. Bedroom and bathroom layouts are efficient and include all the amenities you expect from a Hyatt. But bring your own food and drink...mini bar prices are among the highest I have seen.Service is above average. On check-in, one of two elevators was out of service resulting in a line of people waiting. Staff offered each waiting guest a bottle of water...a small gesture but not so small once you checked the mini bar price list.

Let's start with the compliments for this property...first of all, this is a new hotel, so the entire feel is fresh and clean. The interiors of the lobby, bar and restaurant are all very well done. The artwork above the receptionist desk and bar is an amazing piece and the upholstery selection the lobby area feels warm and inviting. The staff is always attentive and happy to help with whatever you need. The gym of the hotel is well appointed...plenty of cardio equipment and weights. During my stay it was always empty, so you felt that you had a great new modern gym all to yourself. Once inside the rooms, you feel a strong departure from the typical layout, and that is good thing. It is modern, yet inviting and the bed linens are hard to beat. You can tell they actually thought about the guests staying here when they selected all of their finishes. It was done with care and attention to detail.Now the only bad thing is the amount of noise you can hear from your neighbors. The walls seem terribly thin and you can easily hear any conversation that your neighbors are having. Generally not a problem unless you have annoying drunk people coming home at 2am, which I did.For NYC, this is a great hotel...worth a try if you have not and the location is great.

The Hyatt Union Square has a lot going for it and once they work out a few kinks, it will be an excellent place to stay.Location - Union Square is served by so many subway lines that it is easy to get anywhere but sometimes it took longer than expected. Enjoyed the Greenmarket and convenience to LES, Greenwich Village and Chelsea.Accommodations - We stayed in an Urbane King Studio and found it a good size plus the open design helped to make it feel even more spacious. I liked the flooring, lighted closet and the lighting system that provided both bright and ambient lighting. Great water pressure in the shower, super comfortable bed with very soft, luxurious linens. We faced 4th Ave. and the room was super quiet with great blackout shades. No problem with the A/C but would recommend running the fan on medium then you never notice the A/C cycling on and off. Staff - always eager to please. A minor delay at check in and we were given a beautiful cheese plate and nice bottle of wine. We were also given a late checkout which was a great convenience. Obviously the hotel will accommodate you when they can without those unnecessary surcharges.Areas to improve - it took three nights until they got turndown service correct ... Not just the bedding pulled back but also fresh towels, wastebaskets emptied and room tidied. So housekeeping needs to work on this but in other areas, they excel. I never saw the hallways cluttered or littered and the rooms are super clean.Not having wifi was ok - I never expect it in higher end hotels but bottled water in the room would be a nice addition. I just got used to grabbing an extra bottle from the well equipped exercise room.I would definitely stay here again.

Have choosen the Hotel for the great location at Union Square. I would rate it as very comfortable and casual. The rooms are quite basic, however very clean with Laminate floor (feels a bit cheap) and the lightening system and the music system are first class as well as the very comfortable bed and real luxurious soft and crisp linnen. I asked for a Yoga mat and a water cattle, both came after 5 minutes. They offer a bunch of amenities on request, however free of charge and do not fill the room with unnecessary items guests want use. Staff is quite friendly, typical NY-style, very efficient and professional. The adjecent Restaurants seems to be trendy, did not visit. Room rate this time is around US 600.-- so not cheap, however worth the price in view of location.

Needed a hotel near Union Square as we were attending a function near there,not many to choose from so had to pay the $710.00 fee for one night .Very trendy design throught out the hotel and rooms are nice but very small.We didn't use the resturants on site but they looked interesting and if we were staying longer we would have,staff were very pleasant only downside was an hour wait for them to get our car from valet parking.Would defiantly stay again just not sure I want to pay so much for one night .

Caught off guard in New York for in the three-day Labor Day weekend as we had not factored it in and ended our stay too soon at a very nice Flip Key apartment on the upper west side to move downtown to the West Village for a fun weekend. We hurriedly booked anything we could find online which was the Hyatt Union Square. It is fairly new and relatively hard for the experienced taxi driver to find although it has a very prominent corner across Union Square, it is in a very sterile business area, a block or so from the boring Union Square Park, where not only smoking is not allowed; but also no animals, which are usually more exciting than the people in the park! The hotel itself -- run by the LGBT community (which you'd think would give it some "wow" factor or flair, or excitement) -- takes on the same boring, sterile atmosphere as the Park. It attempts, but misses, to be a high end luxury hotel as the other SPG property -- the W, a long standing 5-star boutique hotel several blocks away direct facing the Square. What is does succeed in doing -- even in its infancy -- is duplicating the W's rates. For three nights, even considering the Labor Day weekend, we paid $1,500 -- averaging $500 p/n! Soo not worth it -- even in New York! The king size bed was too hard and not to my liking. Listen, I'm not saying the hotel is bad, it's not. It is modern, trendy (just not my kind of trend) and new. The staff is young but responsive and the rooms are small but well-appointed (although the "garden view" leaves a lot to be desired -- especially from the 9th floor). I am saying that the Hyatt Union Square NY is not ready for prime time and prime time rates -- it has a ways to go! I have and most likely will pay Hyatt Union Square NY rates for a comfortable, luxury stay in New York hotels, but there are too many other hotel choices to choose from and the Hyatt Union Square NY will not be one of them.

I stayed here one night with my husband and found it very nice although it wasn't a high end luxury hotel. It is more modern / trendy / young.The staff was very nice and let us check in at noon which was early. The rooms are small but still a decent size for NY. Our king size bed was extremely comfortable and the linens were super soft. The black out shades blocked out the light completely and even though we were on 4th Ave which is really busy, the windows were completely soundproof. The location is great in the heart of Union Sq. - 1 block from most major subway lines. There are a ton of little restaurants and shopping (it's also easy to walk to W. Village and Soho).The negatives were that wifi isn't complimentary (this always really annoys me - when you're spending several hundreds of $ a night, wifi should always be free). I also called to ask for bottled water and they didn't have any complimentary options (the Fiji bottle in the room was $8 - no thanks!).

Had a wonderful stay at the Hyatt Union Square. This was my first time staying in the Union Square area and I really enjoyed the neighborhood. Transportation was easy to / from the airport and anywhere in Manhattan. The hotel is new and the rooms are very pleasant. I had an excellent stay. Everything was fantastic.

watch out andaz this union square place can give u a run for your value. Lovely place small perfectly placed and great staff and rooms. Only family with kids watch out. Bathrooms have no privacy. Restaurant has good food and so does the bar. Nice atmosphere all around.

3 friends, each single occupancy.There is a heck of a lot going for this boutique hotel.The location - easy walk to LES, West Village, Flatiron and good subway links one block away. Crisp modern design. We had the urban terrace rooms which are great - the bedroom is petite, but the terraces are big and so long as the weather is OK, you have a suite with an open air lounge. My room was at the corner, slightly larger and had the largest terrace, so we had a little drinks party on it with friends from Brooklyn and others! Seating for eight. I can't think of anything else with this at the price. The more standard rooms must be.........more standard. Young laid back staff extremely polite and helpful. I cannot fault them - they're a real credit to the hotel. Couple of small gripes. As is so common, there was not a bright enough light in the room. Reading after dark was too challenging for me, and my sight is not that bad. Vanity light over the mirror too small, and hard to see to shave. No shaving mirror. A sink the depth of a dinner plate which holds about 10mm depth of water (and even that drains with the plug in) does not help. Style over function. Hardly a deal breaker.What could be is the aircon. Early reviews complain that it simply wasn't powerful enough. We had no such issue, so I wonder if they've "turned it up"? If so, the price to pay is that it is way too noisy. All 3 of us had to turn it off, as it's like a truck starting and stopping next to your bed and very difficult to sleep through. It would be a costly issue to fix, but it's what stops this being a perfect hotel. It's why I've given a 2 for sleep quality - the beds themselves are very comfy.We had half an hour to wait for our car Sat brunchtime so we wandered in to the cafe/bar for a drink, where there was obvious friction between the staff and the atmosphere not nice. They were all very stressed. Big contrast with the hotel itself.All things considered I will definitely stay here again. It has a nice vibe - between staid mid-town and LES party. Very convenient and the terrace rooms are a hoot. We were all very pleased with it.

For the last forty years i have been staying in the well known and most expensive hotels both midtown and downtown. With the opening of the Hyatt Union square in May it is like a breath of fresh air in the Manhattan hotel business. I stayed in it twice for a total of 18days. I had the perfect room ( with high quality linen and very comfortable bed) on the 11th floor and the service from the valets, receptionists, housekeeping, room service and maintenance person was extremely, efficient, effective, friendly and professional. The staff is young motivated, happy in their job and well trained. This Hyatt is definitely my new home when I travel to New York.

I travel a lot and haven't stayed at a Hyatt in years. I enjoyed this property quite a bit. The room was nice and the service was very good. ...I wish I could provide better texture in my review, but it was just a nice stay, and sometime if something doesn't stand-out, it's a good thing.

I have stayed here a couple of times now on short business trips and really enjoyed it. The location is great, as it's right near Union Square. It's stylish and well-appointed and the staff are generally very friendly and reasonably helpful. As others have pointed out, the rooms are a bit small for comparable level hotels even in Manhattan, but they are very nicely done. It has a decent fitness center as well. It's one of the new faves on my Manhattan list.

Stayed at this Hyatt for the first time and everything from the moment we walked in was great. Friendly staff, newly renovated rooms, everything you could want! Shower was great, all amenities perfect . Location was wonderful. Could easily walk to lots of great shopping & restaurants. Also, so easy to get to if you're coming thru the Holland Tunnel. We will definitely return!

This is a lovely new Hyatt property in NYC. It's New York, so the rooms are a bit small, but they are beautifully and efficiently appointed, meticulous, and stylish. The staff at the desk could not have been nicer or more gracious. The bar area is comfortable albeit the bartender was a bit full of herself and could have been more attentive. Delicious breakfast with somewhat slow and clueless service, but extremely friendly and warm. Nicely appointed gym for a city property...beautiful bath area. The property was very new during our stay and has probably settled in a bit. I would definitely recommend it for its grace and lovely rooms if you are looking for a hotel in this part of town. Fantastic roof deck with bar that was yet to open at the time I was there.

We stayed at the Hyatt Union Square due to its proximity to the NYU campus. It's diagonal to Union Square and one block from the subway. Check in was perfect as we had prepaid. Our room was ready and the clerk was courteous. The rooms are very modern with many updated amenities such as a large flat screen tv, multiple outlets, coffee maker with Starbucks, rain shower, C. O. Bigelow bath products, and lighted closet units next to the bed. But for the price it's lacking in some areas: there is no soundproofing between the rooms. The family who had the adjoining room next to ours allowed their child to scream at 7:00 am on a Sunday morning. We heard every word. Some of our neighbors received newspapers but we didn't. When I inquired about the paper we were told they ran out. The bath towels are not absorbent, the pillows were very hard, there was poor lighting and no makeup mirror in the bathroom. The hotel is very nice but we were expecting more.

I arrived on a hot and humid afternoon and entered the beautiful lobby of the Hyatt Union Square New York. The lobby looked just like the photographs online but smaller. I was quickly checked into my room (by a laptop, not the advertised iPad® check-in) by a smartly dressed staff member and was even upgraded to an Urbane Sky Room.The room was very small and there was not much space to place my luggage. I liked the modern décor of the room and the natural oak floors instead of carpet. Everything was designed to maximize space and the colors were very relaxing. Expansive floor to ceiling windows (that actually open) helped make the room seem less claustrophobic. The bed was very comfortable and the plush fabric headboard softened the hard lines.As others have mentioned, the heating/cooling system was noisy and did not seem to cool off the room very well. Also, the noise from housekeeping and guests slamming doors did not make for a peaceful stay. If you are looking for peace and quiet, this is not the hotel for you.Overall, I liked this hotel and would probably stay here again. The convenient location and modern decor outweighed the tiny rooms and noise.PROS:-Brand new hotel, stylish lobby with restaurant and bar-Rooms are well designed and modern-Shower has adequate water pressure and is spacious-Close to subway stations and Union Square shopping and diningCONS:-Small rooms, no place to lounge except on the bed or an office chair-You will hear street noise and neighbors closing doors-Strong smell of cleaning products permeate the room-Heating/cooling system is loud and does not cool off room well-Housekeeping is noisy, they don’t pay attention to the privacy sign

My trips to New York have been spent couch surfing and crashing with friends. Aside from a brief 3 hour stay at the Trump, the Hyatt Union Square was my first NY hotel experience. The staff are absolutely wonderful. Gracious and friendly, they helped me feel right at home. Our room was clean, stylish and peaceful. After almost 20 hours a day of trying to see and do everything during our much too short stay, coming back to this hotel was such a relief. We could take our power naps, shower, do a quick outfit change, play music and dance around, have a snack and be on our way again!Good location to get around on foot or subway. And Ippudo is right down the street.I'm more of a Brooklyn lady, but thoroughly enjoyed my stay in this hotel and had a great time hanging out in a different (for me) part of town :)

This was a nice brand new hotel located in an area we had never stayed in before and has few hotels to choose from. Lobby is tastefully decorated and laid out practically. Staff is extremely accommodating. Room is normal size for NYC (small) but laid out extremely well. We had one with floor-to-ceiling windows overlooking 4th Avenue. Good to have sink in separate accessible area. Very comfortable king size bed and pillows. For full disclosure, on the negative side, fire alarm went off at 11 pm for no apparent reason, A/C is a bit loud, and hotel is a bit pricey. Overall, we would definitely stay here again.

My wife and I stayed for one night in July. The staff was very friendly and helpful from the greeter at the door to desk staff, concierge, and maintenance. The fact that we had to deal with maintenance at all is where the trouble was. After checking in, we headed to lunch at a nice restaurant recommended by the concierge. When we got back to the room, it was very obvious that the AC was not working. The maintenance staff could not fix it but offered to move us to another room down the hall an provide us with a small bottle of wine for our trouble.The rooms were nice and very modern but fairly small but I guess that is to be expected in NYC. However there was a bathroom window into the room (not to the outside). The annoying part part about that is that when using the bathroom in the middle of the night, the light shines into the bedroom, thereby waking up your spouse. The other facility issue was thAt the rooftop deck was closed because they didn't have a liquor license for it.Location wise it was very convenient to the Union Square area and only half block away from the park. On the whole, the hotel wasn't bad but there are a lot of hotels in New York. I'd probably try another unless the facility issues can be fixed.

Searching for an hotel near Union Square , I booked Hyatt. The hotel is new and modern.After a first night spent in a basic room, I moved to the second floor where rooms have a private terrace.Bed is very comfortable .room is small but functional The staff at the front desk is always friendly and helpful. You find out very quickly that they care about the guests and it brings a pleasant atmosphere to the lobby. At the restaurant it is a very different treatment. Of course, they don't need a client, it is ok but hotel guests don't need to feel it.I come for lunch, rainy day, restaurant nearly empty ( one guy and his laptop)the room is so cold that I tell the waitress that temperature is too low for a cool and rainy day. She agrees and comes back with an answer from the manager."The air conditioning is set and manager doesn't want to do anything as it will be a hot day tomorrow."If you understand.the answer....let me knowWhy to care ? when the hotel provides new clients everydayWe took an umbrella and went for lunch somewhere else. Front desk at hotel felt sorry and did apologize for their attitude. They didn't have to.

This hotel is a new "hip" hotel, or, not your father's Hyatt! Upon entering the lobby, I thought guests were working at computer work stations, like they have in airports, in the lobby. It was just a long counter with laptops! nope, these are the staff and they were efficient, remembered us and always friendly. The concierge scored us tickets to Kinky Boots and didn't upcharge us as much as Stubhub or ticketliquidaters and they were much better seats.The rooms are small, but most rooms are in NYC. We had been on a ten day trip so we had big luggage we were tripping over in the room. You can't use the vanity without the light being on and seeing it from bed. The shower was great. The room temperature was not. We had it set at 65, as low as it would go and it probably was 72-73 in the room. (three days so it should have gotten there) They have a great heavy comforter on the bed which will be delightful in the winter but with hot rooms and summer, that wasn't great. There is minimal closet space and minimal drawers. They do have a fridge and a coffeemaker in the room, which is nice. If you are going for a quick trip with light luggage, it's great. It's new, fresh, the bar is cool, the restaurant appears cool, it's a great location, stay here!

I stayed here for 3 nights on a biz trip in July. Selected this hotel because I could walk to my client on 16th street. Was this or the W which is too hip for me. Plus I liked that it was a new hotel. I had read the comments about the air conditioning and was a bit concerned. I was there when it was hot ( high 80's) but not the blistering 90's. I was ok but I can see where there would be a problem. I had to set to 67 to feel ok vs my usual 73. And it's hard to explain, but the system does not do a great job cooling and goes on and off a lot. My system at home is pretty loud so I was not awakened but I can see how someone would be.Room size is usual NYC...great for 1 and 2 is a crowd. New and contemporary and I liked the look of the hotel and the room. Arrived and needed a sewing kit and they sent one up in three minutes. Welcoming staff. I ate at the bar one night. Only complaint is that where they keep the liquor is so dark you can't see the bottles...I like to peruse vs. just look at a menu. Food is not nyc's finest but it is good. Great fresh veggies. They have some very high end wines by the glass in a special system that keeps them fresh. I 'm a tequila girl and they had a nice selection.This is a good choice for the Union Square area. I will stay here again when I want to be In this neighborhood.

My first stay at the Hyatt Union Square was only overnight. The hotel had only been open for 2 weeks. Great location. Great amenities. The room was simple with some cool amenities. I arrived after 11pm and the staff were friendly, yet not overtalkative knowing i wanted to head straight to my room after a 15 hour flight from Asia.Hotel had a boutique feel to it, which was in contrast to the Grand Hyatt Grand Central with the huge lobby, numerous lifts, and multitude of check in counters.Loved the boutique feel of the Hyatt Union Square. Will definitely stay here again!

I spent 2 nights here with my girlfriend and was shown a very high level of service. The hotel is setup to be a boutique style hotel. The entrance is very swanky with a great lobby. The hotel staff is dressed in casual almost hipster style clothing which certainly fit the feeling of the hotel. The front desk staff was attentive and knowledgeable. Everyone was pleasant and helpful. It was certainly up to the level of service you'd expect at Hyatt. The adjoining restaurant (Fourth) has a great breakfast. On nice days they open the front wall and you get the cafe style experience. Our breakfast was wonderful and their coffee is top notch.The rooms are small. I had a king room with a decent view. The bed is WONDERFULLY comfortable. The complaints that other people had about the AC was easily taken care of when you set the fan to be always on. With auto turned on the fan will turn on and off almost constantly. The lighting setup is the new fancy Hyatt light switches. There are 3 sets in the room, each of which has a little blue light which keeps the room from getting super dark but it shouldn't keep anyone from being awake.The bathrooms are a cool design. The showers are amazing and the amenities are great. The sink is shallow and a little awkward to wash your hands in but no big deal. The internet was fast and reliable. If you're looking for a nice boutique hotel to use in Union Square then this is a good bet for a couple days. If you need space in your room, this isn't the place for you because you won't get it.The "Business Center" is an iMac in a cubby on a wall in a hallway just off the lobby. It works, but there isn't even a chair...it's a total joke.The fitness center is fantastic. A large selection of new machines, the room is kept to a low temp and there are plenty of machines, and free weights to complete any exercise.

Stayed here for business - this new hotel has huge potential but a lot of kinks to work out.The Bad:They sold my guaranteed room and didn't tell me until a few minutes before I arrived into Penn Station at midnight. The overnight staff handled it extremely poorly and because it was a busy night in Manhattan, couldn't find me another room on the island.The staff, while friendly, generally seems young and inexperienced. One morning, after delivering the wrong newspaper, the woman delivering them complained to me that, at 8:30, it was too early to be working. She was trying to be friendly, but clearly hasn't been trained on guest interaction.The bar area, while lovely, isn't staffed up enough - we had to get up and ask for our bar tab each night because nobody ever came back.The breakfast room service menu is odd - needs more simpler choices.My colleague had a number of issues with the service in the restaurant - I never tried it.The Good:Great location near Union Square.As others have mentioned, a boutique addition to the Hyatt properties in Manhattan. Much cooler vibe.William, the front desk manager, took care of my oversold situation the next day and provided excellent service all week.The bed is ridiculously comfortable. Shower is great, too.Corner rooms (upgrade) have a sitting area and a bit more space than the standard rooms.Overall, while I was incredibly frustrated by my first impression (being bumped and how poorly it was handled), the hotel did make it up to me and this will likely become my business home in Manhattan.

Had some time to kill and made a quick (2day) trip to NYC to meet some friends and site-see. I've been to NYC many times but hard to get one of my usual favorites so chose the Hyatt Union Sq and was not disappointed. Staff was extremely friendly, hotel was clean and my loft room was large and extremely comfortable. And despite being a major chain the hotel had a slight boutique feel and was not massive, with is my preference. And Union Square is a great location with easy access to the major subway lines. Did not eat there but friends had dinner and stated excellent.

The staff was plentiful, enthusiastic, responsive and good problem-solvers. This is not the typical corporate Hyatt - going more for the boutique style of hotel. Small rooms. Quiet. Good location on Union Sq which puts you in the action when you step outside. Adjoining restaurant, The Fourth, not part of the Hyatt, but convenient and excellent, interesting food.

From the minute I walked into the lobby to check in, until the minute I checked out (on the TV), my experience at the Hyatt Union Square was EXCELLENT!!!!! Fast and easy checkin, courteous staff, great lobby, lounge, and restaurant, well sized and beautifully appointed rooms. The bed was INCREDIBLY comfortable- I did not want to get out of bed each morning for my meetings!!!! Love the touch lighting system, and bar amenities. Easy to adjust room temp, FANTASTIC blackout shades so that it, literally could have been bright sunshine outside at any time, but in my room it was dark dark dark.GREAT location, hip neighborhood. Love love love this hotel!!!! I'LL BE BACK!

Brand new property located in Union Square. Fantastic. Check-in smooth, quick and very courteous. Staffed by 20-something's but no sense smugness. Very kind and efficient. Cool, hip bar and lounge off lobby in both directions. Pricey, but about as expected for new property and location(NYC AND Union Sq). Rooms are very very small, even by NYC standards. Too small at this price point. However, they are well laid out with a king bed( yes, I know it takes up a lot of space) and new fixtures(flat screen etc...). Bathroom: even small but shower is decent sized and shower head is angled(not directly over head) rain type. Very good pressure and nice(Bigelow?) amenities. Details: never received newspaper that check-in asked me to choose(NY Times). No welcome amenity(perhaps not entitled. No big deal). Just down street from busy fire station. Very busy.Overall, as mentioned a very well located hotel with a few quirks. Likely will return but might try Andaz on 41st as well.

I am currently staying in this hotel and frequently visit nyc for business and vacation. This hotel had attractive rates to promote it's opening just off union square great location. Incredibly friendly and helpful staff answered all my questions and didn't argue when I said the website deal had free in room wifi. A few downsides - the hotel needs some finishing touches. The faucets on the sinks are so low you can barely get your hands in easily between the faucet and the sink. The toilet door didn't shut or lock... I told the staff at 8am and when I returned around 230pm not only was the issue unresolved but the room hadn't even been made up. Clearly some links yet to iron out of this otherwise excellent new Hyatt.

Just opened in April, hotel is nice and sparking new. Location is Union Square, nothing else needs to be said about that, its fabulous, steps away from everything. My breakdown:Pros:Sparkling rooms, firm to my comfort bed, hip interior, amazing views with our urbane sky room, very friendly staff, actually too friendly, prompt service - room service and a request for a toothbrush were lighting fast delivered. Very nice bar in lobby to grab a drink. I loved the hard wood floors in the room, sheets were nice and room was functional. Its small, but anything in NYC is.Cons:Poor layout, hallways not airy for full of light, they did turndown service at 5pm a little early I think, front door staff not helpful, they were not really there at all times, didnt help with luggage and seemed busy chatting with themselves. Sink is not deep, expect flooding. Bathroom toilet could use some more elbow space. A lot of the switches have neon lights that glow in the dark bright, so you never really get a fully dark room to sleep in, also the fiber cables behind the TV flicker on/off all night disrupting the already lack of darkness in the room at night. The air conditioner is horrible, never cold enough, kept on cicking on/off every 3 minutes, very loud, actually the street noise didnt bother me, but the AC is a no win. It bothered me enough that I wouldnt go back to this hotel if I needed to use the AC.Other than that, reasonable price 250 + tax for a nights stay.

I stayed at the Hyatt Union Sq last night & overall, had a pleasant stay. The hotel has some room for improvement. I had some good & weak points to mention, so I'll break down my review into pros/cons:Pros:- Alyssa at check in was amazing! She was very kind, gave me a lovely upgrade (room #901) & was cool, yet refined. Well done & thank you! - Meagan from In Room Dining who delivered my breakfast was super- warm, efficient & very kind! The young guy who delivered my dinner was also really lovely- both were so nice! - The shower is absolutely amazing! Perfect water pressure & very clean. - The CO Bigelow bath products were lovely- I love the Lavender Peppermint scent...perfect for the summer. - The location in Union Square is amazing- a very hip, cool neighborhood in downtown NYC. Near some amazing restaurants, lively street life, Whole Foods, Think Coffee, Union Sq park, etc. - The lobby had a lovely smell & was very aesthetically pleasing. Cons:-Extremely Limited Room Service Menu- it's provided by the hotels restaurant, The Fourth, but the selection offered is very strange & not ideal for guests who are looking for more simple dining options for in room dining. - The girl who checked me out on the morning of 7/5 was not very friendly at all. She hardly made eye contact, never asked me how my stay was, never offered assistance with luggage, & was borderline uninterested in her job. This was a Fail on all levels. - The bed, while comfy, was way too heavy for the summer. A lighter comforter would have been really nice, but it was so late. - My room was extremely bright, which would have been fine. However, it was extremely hot + humid outside & my room was very small, which was not ideal- I think this contributed to the room always feeling warm. - The A/C was cool, but could have been much colder. I honestly felt like my room never was cold enough for me- just a personal preference. Overall, if you want to stay in this part of New York, I think the hotel is an ideal choice. I think the W in Union Square is much better in terms of service, dining & is similar in price. I'm a fan of both Park Hyatt & Andaz, both under the Hyatt group. This was a bit of a let down, but I'm still happy I tried the hotel. In no way did I have a bad stay, just wanted to give some honest feedback. Best,Patrick Winkler

The website advertises valet parking but there was no one to take my car & nowhere to stop so I had to go around the block (not easy in nyc). The valet told me it was cheaper to park in a garage & carry my bags inside so I did. Then I requested extra towels and an air conditioning check up and when I returned to my room at midnight-9 hours later- no towels and no one ever came to fix the AC so we were very hot all night.The staff was very nice but since my issues were not properly addressed, I would consider them ineffective. I really wanted to like this hotel but I was so hot & sticky that I couldn't.

The Hyatt Union square is an ideal location for any downtown activities. The price is almost $300 per night cheaper than other big name hotels in the area. The hotel was very clean and everyone that worked there was friendly and helpful. Definitely a cool place to stay for anyone looking to go out in the city and not drop big bucks on a place to stay.

Had a fun overnight, the location was quite convenient for our needs (events in Chelsea & the East Village). We got a nice surprise: an upgrade to a king room, outside facing on the 5th floor, at the end of the hall. Quiet actually (other than thin walls - you can hear the anyone's shower from the hallway), but then again traffic at this part of Union Square is more like DC vs. NYC. The decor & design were clever & soothing, & maybe most importantly made efficient use of space in the traditional small footprint of a hotel in NYC. Examples: Pocket doors between the sleeping area & the bathroom, the bathroom & the toilet; the mini bar console was an oval design that fit well close to the entry, without having hard edges that would've clashed with the space. Loved the green cooling system (turns on only when you're in the room) & light controls. The plastic molded wall with the wavy design made the room seem less closet like too. The onsite gym was pretty BIG compared to what I've seen at larger hotels. The roof top terrace was scenic enough but kind of boring & not a "scene" really, sans bar or hot tub. I'd highly recommend the bar, Singl: GREAT cocktails, sharp service, wine selection may seem limited but is carefully thought-out. Extensive scotch & whisky selection. We didn't eat in the restaurant, which seemed would definitely rival something at say a Kimpton, but we did get excellent bar & dinner fare at Singl (very boutique-y). Service was low key, friendly, & efficient. Our porter honestly advised us we'd probably pay less at the public parking garage across the street (we did - $50 for overnight vs. $60 with the hotel). We were lucky - no sour notes, but that apparently wasn't the case with some other guests we overheard at checkout. The main areas for improvement might be a) a different configuration for the front desk to allow for more privacy, b) free WiFi throughout (free only in the lobby, seriously?!), & something to spice up the roof top terrace. We'd stay here again in a heartbeat.

Stayed here over the Memorial Day weekend for my wife's birthday, and had such an incredible time. The hotel is brand new, but the staff made the entire stay smooth and perfect. A special thanks to Carlos Orihuela, the assistant general manager, for his kind hospitality - Carlos is a truly exceptional hospitality professional. I had booked an Alcove Loft with Hyatt Gold Passport points, but was offered an eStandby upgrade to a suite in the confirmation email. We were indeed upgraded to the ~600 square foot Empyreal (penthouse) suite. It had a spacious, nicely furnished sitting area with an amazing city view (including the Con Edison clock and the Empire State Building), as well as a dining area. The bedroom was large and luxurious with an amazing view; there was a huge double shower that maintained excellent water pressure and temperature for two. All requests were immediately met with courteous fulfillment. I will most definitely return, and am unlikely to ever stay anywhere else in NYC again.

We stayed at the Hyatt for our anniversary and it was absolutely outstanding on every levels. In my book this won the best Hotel in NYC, and let me tell you why.First the location. It's located one block away from Union Square, which is a major subway/metro station connecting to almost everywhere in NY. You're basically one or two metro stations away from anywhere in New York, avoiding the chaos and the tourists in Times Square and Mid-town. In Union Square itself you have the Whole foods, where we used to grab breakfast (they have fresh breakfast buffet at 7:30AM), take the metro and eat it in Central Park...it just starts the day perfectly! You also have a drug store, Starbuck, movie theater, shops, coffee shops, Eataly (amazing Italian market). Hyatt Union Square is the perfect addition in the neighborhood and is way more conveniant than anywhere else!We entered the hotel, we were amazed how beautiful and clean it was...just like the rooms....it's not just clean...it's ''OCD'' type of clean! The lobby looks great, like the decor, the lounge was closed (it opens at 4PM) but just looking at it made us want to hang out and have a drink or two. The staff upon our arrival was smiling, great attitude, we felt very welcome and for once in New York they made us feel like we are very important for them. Trust me I had a lot of requests and quesions and they made absolutely everything possible to accomodate me and even go the extra mile! Nowhere in New York I ever experienced this level of service....ever!...not even in the classic 5 star luxury hotels....where they make you feel like they are doing you a favor.....but that's for another review. While they were making sure everything in the room was all set (again I had a few request prior our arrival which I arranged with Jeremy the concierge who was also fantastic by the way), we decided to go have a few drinks at the Fourth, so we sat at the bar (the Singl lounge was closed...we were early for check-in) and realized that the bartender was speaking fluent french...she was absolutely amazing, she helped us and guided us with our itinerary and a few tips for our stay over the long week-end. She also (on her own initiative) provided information and backgroud on all the arts and designs from the Fourth. Once you understand the artist more...it makes a lot of sense! Great start to our journey!Now the room....it was HUGE! (about 567 sf) It was clean (as I mentionned earlier) it smelled great and I had everything I asked for in the room including a little treat from the Hotel itself....a nice little attention which was very much appreciated! We stayed in the Empyreal Suite, amazing decor, you walk in the dining room, then the living room, you also have a connecting bathroom with the bedroom and the washroom which is also enormous! They use every little bit of space brillantly, the design is not comparable to anything, it's very fresh, very modern and hip....and it also smelled great in the room! You have control pannels everywhere in the room which controls the lights (master, different moods and ambiance) the temperature and also the sheers and curtains....everything is electrical and automatic...it's great! There is windows (floor to ceiling) everywhere, plenty of natural lights at all time. And the bed...OMG...so comfortable! You will fall asleep without even noticing it! There are plenty of space in the room...two very large closets where you can hang your clothing and also drawers and cabinets to put everything away...even two large suitacases!The bathroom is huge, two sinks with mirrors so we can use it at the same time, the toilet is also isolated from the bathroom. The shower?? We can fit a football team in there! We always took our shower together...felt like we were in a luxury locker room! :PThe gym is also huge....this is the best gym I ever went to in any hotel, you have top of the line equipment (and a LARGE variety of it), cold fresh towels in a fridge with fruits and water available. Too bad we didn't have time to use it! The rooftop terrace is also quite large, there is room for 20-25 people to sit comfortably, different tables, chairs, beds...etc. However they have no alcohol licence for the rooftop so no bar and you're not allowed bringing alcohol either...but it's ok.The only thing is there is no fridge in the room to keep cold beverages for when we get back to the only after walking all day. There is also no ice machine, you have to call in-room service to order some. But the good news is I never had to ask for it, after my first call upon my arrival, they made sure I had Ice everyday and they put the champagne in a bucket ready for our arrival every single day! They scored major points with that too!They have the turndown service, they prepare the room for the night with lights / sheers / curtains setting, and a little treat everyday on the bed. We liked that a lot.Last thing, the price....VERY reasonnable, I noticed that they lowered the price by 100$/night on all room category about a month before we arrived, which made us decide to upgrade. With the price reduction.....it's cheaper than other hotels and you get a LOT more!I will also post pictures to give you a better idea, but thanks again to all Hyatt people, I don't remember all of the names but you all contributed to an amazing week-end in New York and you have us now...we'll get back every year!Thank you so much, Francois Morin

We stayed at this Hotel and it was oustanding.The ambiance was great; the room was perfectHowever, the main compliment shoud go to the front desk staff:Nailah and Jeremy were so thoughtful and helpful and possessed with great smiles and a can-do enthusiasm. They made the trip!and their manager, Cheryl Huse was great.

Hotel is Brand new. I am sure it will only get better with time. Rooftop is open but no bar, overall ambiance is very nice and clean. Needs a bit of a hip kick to put it in the full category of NY boutique hotels, but I'll take mind over matter. It's the New kid on the block in Union Square so that says enough.

My wife and I stayed at this hotel about 2 weeks ago. First thing you notice is that the location to UNION Square is like a block or so. It’s like a 7 minute walk to Whole FOODS and a 2 minute walk to a Hipster Coffee Bar called "Think Coffee". As we first walked in we were greeted by 2 people in the front and felt very welcomed immediately. We walked in and loved the lobby, it is nearby a restaurant next door in which you can see a huge wood piece of art hanging on the roof going down 15 feet. I don’t know what the heck it was, look liked a bunch of wooden chairs, but wow!!When walking into our studio room, we noticed that it had glass sliding doors leading into a patio area with plants and ivy. Place is so warm and makes you want to stay in the hotel room. Usually you feel like you’re in a hotel, UNION SQUARE HYATT felt as if your home. I noticed by walking around the hotel there was a lot of YOUNG (25-33) diverse faces working on the staff. All staff was clean cut and had college degrees. Many types of faces which include an Asian, Hispanic, African American, and white. The best of the crop of each ethnic background, not gritty people. Usually at hotels you see old people hustling for tips. I feel bad saying it, but this hotel felt like it had more energy than the old Grand Hyatt. The rooms were beautiful and really used up the space wisely. There was a comfortable HYATT queen bed with the HYATT linens. HYATT gear for sleeping is very high quality! The shower had exquisite oval tile, looked incredible! I was really surprised to see how small the room was but yet it was so comforting. Like previously noted, "I FELT like it was home". The gym was just small and perfect, it’s also 24 hours!!! It was empty when I went at around 930 ish, the only people I saw were people going in to get the complimentary water bottles in the refrigerator. The gym has a bench , some dumbbells, cardio machines (With the tv screens/internet), couple of yoga mats, etc. Just enough to get a great workout in. They also offer complimentary towels. You really do not have to leave the hotel for anything. At the end, I was quite sad for leaving. But will return…. Before I left I spoke to DAVID QUINS, front desk supervisor, and told him what a great hotel Union Square HYATT is and what a great job his staff is doing! Will definitely come back!!!!!!!!!!!!

I stayed at this new Hyatt near Union Square about a month ago and was very pleasantly surprised by this property. The rooms are small (but no more than most other NYC properties), and they have done a wonderful making job making great use of the space (especially in the sink/bathroom area and with closet space). The property has a modern feel to it (without being over the top), and i found it to be very comfortable. I probably would not bring the kids here, but it is a great spot for singles and married couples (and for business folks during the week). The price was incredibly reasonable for a spring NYC weekend, and it has a great and subway-convenient location.

I come here often for work and this is by far the best hotel I've stayed at -- such a reasonable rate and it totally looks and feels like a W property. The rooms are awesome -- comfortable bed, gorgeous lighting, hip decor. Highly recommend.

My wife and I enjoyed our stay at the Hyatt Union Square New York. We celebrated our anniversary there and stayed three nights. The hotel's location, just below Union Square on Fourth Avenue at 13th St. is very convenient for all types of activities because it is just on the edge of the East Village, close to the West Village, on Union Square, and has easy access to lower Manhattan, midtown, and the Bronx, Queens and Brooklyn via subway.We enjoyed the relaxed, but very comfortable, atmosphere at the hotel. Its not like any Hyatt you've been to before - it gives the feeling of a trendy, independent hotel. The staff is very pleasant and friendly, and although the rooms are small, they are well-decorated, functional, and relaxing. The front desk staff don't wear traditional uniforms and the front desk - well its not really a front desk. I think Hyatt has learned a lot from their Hyatt Place experiences, with a less formal approach to registration and check in. This hotel works well, but it feels more personal and friendly than other Hyatt's I've stayed in.I usually stay in midtown hotels when in NYC, but I liked this stay and I think I will be here when I have the opportunity. I liked being near the restaurants of the Village, with quick access to Chinatown, SOHO and the lower east side. We walked a great deal, including an epic trek to the World Trade Center.We also went to Brooklyn one evening and it was great to be able to take just one subway almost to the hotel's door.The Hyatt Union Square New York is a great addition to the neighborhood and a good option for business or pleasure trips to NYC.

I had made a reservation to use a Hyatt Stay Certificate at this new Hyatt property. I was really excited to try this new addition to the Hyatts in NYC. However, I needed two beds and the hotel told me I needed to pay an extra $300 to get a room with two beds. I've heard of a $25 or $50 premium for two-bedded rooms but $300 extra for a second bed is ridiculous. I also felt the tone of the response from the sales manager to be rude.

$62 for Macallan 18 yr? Cheapest beer is $9. Come on! Also, no signature cocktail that cost $14-16 should use Beefeater as primary ingredient, especially for an upscale NYC bar/lounge.Only reason I gave "poor" instead of "terrible" is the ambiance and decor is nice.

Overall, it was nice, I was supposedly upgraded to a nicer room, but it was very small. Makes me wonder how small the standard rooms are....enjoyed the brassiere on site, but it was expensive. I'd come back if hotel was less expensive than the other NYC Hyatt, otherwise prefer the Andaz or Hyatt near Grand Central

I live next door and had a issue with getting locked out of my apartment. A gentleman at the front helped me out and talked to me about the history of the hotel and I was so happy at his kindness I put my brother up there for a night when he was in town. I think that finding good customer service in new york is hard to find but I got treated very well and it really mattered that they were nice to my younger brother. I will be using them next time family visits.

We recently stayed for one night with two rooms for NYU graduation. We received rooms 310 and 309, which were slightly noisy but not too bad. The rooms were pretty nice, although very small and the bathroom would be uncomfortable for people sharing a room other than significant others. In one of the rooms, the Air Conditioning didn't seem to work 100%. The bathrooms have nice toiletries - C.O. Bigelow. The TVs are nice and have HD channels - always a plus. We didn't try it but the gym looked nice. The location was very convenient to the subway and restaurants and shops. The restaurant for breakfast was pretty good, but expensive and one of the orders came out wrong (but it was still good). Service was friendly but simple tasks like getting luggage up to the room and calling when the rooms were available were made difficult. One last note - the mini fridge diet pepsi was slightly expired and warm, usually okay but it stunk considering it was $5 for 8 ounces. The hotel was overall nice and after a few more months of operation, it will probably be great, albeit slightly form over function-y.

I'm writing this review keeping in mind that the hotel had been open less than a month when we stayed a couple of weeks ago. I wish I could give 3.5 stars, but am giving 4 fully expecting that once the kinks are ironed out, this will be an exceptional property for the location (i.e. the rooms are tiny).The first thing I have to comment on is the exceptionally kind and helpful staff. From the front desk, to the valet, to the guest services line, everyone was incredibly accommodating. One evening I called down asking for a can opener and the woman who answered thought I said kennel - yes like a kennel for my French bulldog - and said she didn't know if they had any but would see if she could locate one I could borrow. Hilarious, but I never would have known that's what happened if I didn't call back half an hour later requesting the can opener. It does say that she was really interested in helping me!Also I guess because my husband is a Diamond member, for 2 nights there was either a fruit platter with a half bottle of chianti, or a cheese plate with a half bottle of chianti - a nice bottle too - Ruffino.
